title: The Word Made Flesh
shortSummary: John chapter 1 introduces Jesus Christ as the eternal Word who was with God and is God, emphasizing His divine nature and role in creation. It also presents John the Baptist's testimony about Jesus, the calling of the first disciples, and the revelation of Jesus as the Messiah and Son of God. This chapter lays the foundation for understanding Jesus’ identity and mission.
timeline: c. AD 27-30 - Beginning of Jesus' public ministry

keyCharacters.name: Jesus Christ
keyCharacters.description: The eternal Word made flesh, the Messiah, and Son of God who reveals God to humanity and brings grace and truth.

keyCharacters.name: John the Baptist
keyCharacters.description: A prophet sent from God to bear witness to Jesus as the true Light and Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world.

keyCharacters.name: Andrew
keyCharacters.description: One of John the Baptist’s disciples who becomes a follower of Jesus and brings his brother Simon Peter to Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Philip
keyCharacters.description: A disciple called by Jesus who finds Nathanael and testifies about Jesus as the one foretold in Scripture.

keyCharacters.name: Nathanael
keyCharacters.description: A skeptic from Nazareth who comes to faith in Jesus after Jesus reveals supernatural knowledge about him.

definitions.definition: A title for Jesus emphasizing His preexistence, divine nature, and role as God’s self-expression and agent of creation.
The anointed one promised in the Old Testament, the Savior and King sent by God to redeem His people.
A ritual of cleansing and repentance involving water, symbolizing purification and preparation for the coming kingdom.
A title for Jesus signifying His role as the perfect sacrifice who takes away the sins of the world.
Key attributes of Jesus’ ministry contrasting the law given through Moses with the saving mercy and reality revealed in Christ.

outline.heading: The Eternal Word and Creation
outline.description: This section declares the preexistence of the Word, His unity with God, and His role as Creator and source of life and light that overcomes darkness.

outline.heading: John the Baptist’s Testimony
outline.description: John the Baptist is introduced as a witness to the true Light, Jesus, whom he identifies as the Lamb of God who takes away the world’s sin and the Son of God.

outline.heading: The Calling of the First Disciples
outline.description: Jesus begins to call His first followers, including Andrew, Simon Peter, Philip, and Nathanael, revealing His identity as the Messiah and promising greater revelations.

application: Recognize Jesus as the eternal Word and Creator, deepening your worship and trust in His divine authority.
Follow John the Baptist’s example by bearing clear witness to Jesus as the Light and Savior in your daily life.
Respond to Jesus’ call to discipleship with immediate obedience and invite others to come and see Him.
Trust in the grace and truth that Jesus brings, allowing His light to overcome darkness in your heart.

keyVerses.text: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
keyVerses.significance: This foundational verse affirms Jesus’ eternal deity and unity with God, establishing His divine nature.

keyVerses.text: And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the incarnation, God becoming man in Jesus, displaying His glory and character.

keyVerses.text: The next day John seeth Jesus coming unto him, and saith, Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.
keyVerses.significance: John the Baptist’s declaration identifies Jesus as the sacrificial Lamb who removes sin, central to salvation.

keyVerses.text: But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the promise of adoption into God’s family through faith in Jesus.
